title: Getting Started
text: Example data original paper included package. ’ll use demonstration. data called lord_jcb. basic SuperPlot can generated following code:  generate SuperPlot Speed data, Treatment x-axis Replicate used group data. y-axis label set “Speed”. equivalent call long form :
code: library(SuperPlotR) #> Error in get(paste0(generic, ".", class), envir = get_method_env()) :  #>   object 'type_sum.accel' not found superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") superplot(   df = lord_jcb,   meas = "Speed",   cond = "Treatment",   repl = "Replicate",   ylab = "Speed (µm/min)" )

title: Getting Started
text: separate vignette describes customise sizing plot. , look major customisation options.

title: Getting Started
text: underlying data can rendered violins,  jittered scatter plot, default (shown first example page) uses sina jittered scatter plot density estimate.
code: superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", datadist = "violin") superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", datadist = "jitter")

title: Getting Started
text: colours points can changed. default Paul Tol’s bright palette ("tol_bright") can select : "tol_bright" "tol_vibrant" "tol_muted" "tol_light" Color Universal Design ("cud")  ’s possible supply palette vector colours (hex description format)
code: superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", pal = "cud") superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", pal = c("#ff0000", "blue", "green"))

title: Getting Started
text: mean replicate shown default. can show median instead

title: Getting Started
text: default SuperPlot include bars indicate mean ± error. can added using bars argument. Options : "mean_sd" = mean ± standard deviation "mean_sem" = mean ± standard error mean "mean_ci" = mean ± 95% confidence interval Note bars show mean ± error replicate means underlying data points.

title: Getting Started
text: default, data points circles. want use different shapes different conditions, can use shapes argument. Set TRUE use different shapes replicate.  ’d like link summary points, set linking = TRUE.  Linkages can made two groups. demonstrate use toy data:
code: superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", shapes = TRUE) superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", linking = TRUE) set.seed(123) example <- data.frame(meas = rep(rep(c(10, 9, 6, 6), each = 25), 4) + rnorm(400),                       cond = rep(rep(c("ctrl", "drug 1", "drug 2", "drug 3"), each = 25), 4),                       expt = rep(c("exp1","exp2","exp3","exp4"), each = 100)) superplot(example, "meas", "cond", "expt",           linking = TRUE)

title: Getting Started
text: SuperPlot can saved PDF PNG file using ggsave function ggplot2 package.
code: library(ggplot2) p <- superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",                ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") ggsave("superplot.pdf", p) #> Saving 6 x 4 in image

title: Getting Started
text: separate vignette describes customise SuperPlot . See vignette("advanced").

title: Advanced Usage
text: vignette, explore advanced features SuperPlotR. first, need deal simply scale plot looks good paper!

title: Advanced Usage
text: default setting use point sizes 2 data 3 summary points. font size 12. looks good RStudio viewer, well suited figure likely small.   look great viewer, look better figure.  preferable
code: library(SuperPlotR) #> Error in get(paste0(generic, ".", class), envir = get_method_env()) :  #>   object 'type_sum.accel' not found # the default plot superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") # the same plot but with custom sizing superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)",           size = c(0.8,1.5), fsize = 9) library(ggplot2) # the same plot but with custom sizing superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",                ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", size = c(0.8,1.5), fsize = 9) ggsave("plot.pdf", width = 88, height = 50, units = "mm") # final size library(ggplot2) # the same plot but with custom sizing superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",                ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") ggsave("plot.pdf", width = 88, height = 50, units = "mm") # final size

title: Advanced Usage
text: couple simple tweaks: x label can added, transparency points can altered like .  SuperPlotR returns ggplot object can customised like. example, theme can overridden like :  can also accept ggplot object using gg parameter, add SuperPlot (within reason!). example, might want plot something behind SuperPlot.
code: superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",           xlab = "Drug", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", alpha = c(0.3,1)) p <- superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") p + theme_minimal() p <- ggplot() +   geom_hline(yintercept = 20, linetype = "dashed", col = "grey") superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)", gg = p)

title: Advanced Usage
text: best done reordering levels factor input dataframe calling superplot.  also possible reorder Replicates using similar strategy. might want order colours shapes matches different order default. Another way achieve thing supply reordered colour palette superplot.
code: df <- lord_jcb df$Treatment <- factor(df$Treatment, levels = c("Drug", "Control")) superplot(df, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)")

title: Making non-SuperPlots - FlatPlots
text: SuperPlotR designed make SuperPlots, sometimes just want simple plot. vignette show make “FlatPlot” using SuperPlotR. contrast SuperPlots, emphasise experimental replicates, FlatPlots flat structure, replicates shown. can used look data single experiment, replicates individual data points.  Many arguments superplot(), replicate argument used.  control colour single colour, can hex code one lab’s publication colour palette.  can request statistical testing SuperPlots, p-values calculated whole dataset, replicate.  example, increased size points, made slightly transparent, added error bars show mean 95% confidence interval.
code: library(SuperPlotR) #> Error in get(paste0(generic, ".", class), envir = get_method_env()) :  #>   object 'type_sum.accel' not found flatplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", ylab = "Speed (um/min)") flatplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", ylab = "Speed (um/min)",          colour = "rl_green") flatplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", ylab = "Speed (um/min)",          colour = "rl_red", stats = TRUE) #> Performing t-test #>  #>  Welch Two Sample t-test #>  #> data:  x and y #> t = 8.7438, df = 279.51, p-value < 2.2e-16 #> alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>   7.738602 12.235350 #> sample estimates: #> mean of x mean of y  #>  31.58355  21.59657 flatplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", ylab = "Speed (um/min)",          colour = "rl_red", size = 4, alpha = 0.25,          bars = "mean_ci")

title: Limitations to SuperPlotR
text: limitations SuperPlotR. vignette covers offers solutions possible.

title: Limitations to SuperPlotR
text: Facetting partially supported. simple scenario facetting replicate, can :  another variable wished facet , facetting variable possible, limitation: summary points remain replicate summary therefore facet. may want.  Solution: best way achieve “facetting” currently (correct summary points) make SuperPlot variable, .e. filtering data frame B, combine using patchwork similar package.
code: library(SuperPlotR) #> Error in get(paste0(generic, ".", class), envir = get_method_env()) :  #>   object 'type_sum.accel' not found library(ggplot2) p <- superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate",                ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") p + facet_wrap(~Replicate) df <- cbind(lord_jcb, other = rep(c("A", "B"), 150)) p <- superplot(df, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", ylab = "Speed (µm/min)") p + facet_wrap(~other)

title: Limitations to SuperPlotR
text: dataset conditions replicates numeric, SuperPlotR converts character plotting. intended behaviour SuperPlot. Currently, data Conditions numeric, example time points, unevenly spaced, e.g. 0, 1, 3, 9 hours; appear evenly spaced x-axis. limitation current implementation. Raise issue like changed.

title: Limitations to SuperPlotR
text: Adding p-values stars SuperPlot currently supported due number different ways users may wish add . However, possible add manually SuperPlot object generated. SuperPlotR statistical testing (simple way) turned default. can turn setting stats = TRUE call superplot(). Four types statistical tests available: t-test, Wilcoxon rank sum test, ANOVA Kruskal-Wallis test. Select options setting stats_test one following: "para_unpaired" (default), "para_paired", "nonpara_unpaired" "nonpara_paired". number conditions two, options result : "para_unpaired": t-test "para_paired": paired t-test "nonpara_unpaired": Wilcoxon rank sum test .k.Mann-Whitney U test "nonpara_paired": Wilcoxon signed rank test number conditions greater two, options result : "para_unpaired": ANOVA followed Tukey’s HSD test "para_paired": Repeated measures ANOVA "nonpara_unpaired": Kruskal-Wallis test "nonpara_paired": direction perform Friedman test Returning example data, Lord et al. paper perform paired t-test data. can SuperPlotR setting stats = TRUE stats_test "para_paired". example, generate test data four treatments.
code: p <- superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", stats = TRUE) #> Performing t-test #>  #>  Welch Two Sample t-test #>  #> data:  x and y #> t = 1.2907, df = 3.8128, p-value = 0.2695 #> alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  -11.91888  31.89283 #> sample estimates: #> mean of x mean of y  #>  31.58355  21.59657 p <- superplot(lord_jcb, "Speed", "Treatment", "Replicate", stats = TRUE,                stats_test = "para_paired") #> Performing t-test #>  #>  Paired t-test #>  #> data:  x and y #> t = 8.1741, df = 2, p-value = 0.01464 #> alternative hypothesis: true mean difference is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>   4.730053 15.243899 #> sample estimates: #> mean difference  #>        9.986976 set.seed(123) example <- data.frame(meas = rep(rep(c(10, 9, 6, 6), each = 25), 4) + rnorm(400),                       cond = rep(rep(c("ctrl", "drug 1", "drug 2", "drug 3"), each = 25), 4),                       expt = rep(c("exp1","exp2","exp3","exp4"), each = 100)) superplot(example, "meas", "cond", "expt", linking = TRUE,           stats_test = "para_unpaired")

title: Authors and Citation
text: Royle S (2025). SuperPlotR: Making SuperPlots R. R package version 0.0.5, https://quantixed.github.io/SuperPlotR/, https://github.com/quantixed/SuperPlotR.
code: @Manual{,   title = {SuperPlotR: Making SuperPlots in R},   author = {Stephen J Royle},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.0.5, https://quantixed.github.io/SuperPlotR/},   url = {https://github.com/quantixed/SuperPlotR}, }

title: Making SuperPlots in R
text: goal SuperPlotR allow user easily generate SuperPlots R. SuperPlots way visualise data way emphasises experimental reproducibility. can read SuperPlots original paper: Lord, S.J., Velle, K.B., Mullins, R.D. & Fritz-Laylin, L.K. (2020) SuperPlots: Communicating reproducibility variability cell biology. J. Cell Biol. 219(6):e202001064

title: Making SuperPlots in R
text: can install development version SuperPlotR GitHub :

title: Making SuperPlots in R
text: simple example use SuperPlotR shown :  data used example included package original paper. generate SuperPlot, need data frame least three columns. columns : variable measured experiment, experimental condition, experimental repeat measurment comes . superplot function takes data frame, names three columns, customisable additional arguments. See vignette("SuperPlotR") examples, vignette("advanced") advanced usage.

title: Making SuperPlots in R
text: SuperPlot package IGOR Pro available popular web-based app generating SuperPlots, developed Joachim Goedhart available

what: Add Mean ± Error Bars to a SuperPlot — add_sp_bars
title: Add Mean ± Error Bars to a SuperPlot — add_sp_bars
Add Mean ± Error Bars to a SuperPlot — add_sp_bars
Add Mean ± Error Bars to a SuperPlot — add_sp_bars
text: p ggplot object bars character string, one "mean_sd", "mean_sem", "mean_ci" df data frame summary data (supplied superplot()) cond character string condition column rep_summary character string replicate summary column

title: Add Mean ± Error Bars to a SuperPlot — add_sp_bars
Make a FlatPlot — flatplot
code: flatplot(   df,   meas,   cond,   colour = "#000000",   xlab = "",   ylab = "Measurement",   datadist = "sina",   size = 2,   alpha = 0.5,   bars = "mean_sd",   fsize = 12,   gg = NULL,   stats = FALSE,   stats_test = "para_unpaired" )

title: Make a FlatPlot — flatplot
text: df data frame least three columns: meas, cond, repl meas character name column measurement (e.g. intensity) cond character name column condition (e.g. Control, WT) colour string colour palette use, select ("rl_green", "rl_red", "rl_blue", "rl_purple", "rl_orange", "rl_magenta", hex colour, default black) xlab string x label (default empty) ylab string y label (default "Measurement") datadist string data distribution use, select ("sina" default, "jitter") size numeric size data points (default 2) alpha numeric vector alpha range data summary points (default c(0.5, 0.7)) bars string type error bars add, select ("none", "mean_sd" (default), "mean_sem", "mean_ci") fsize numeric font size text (default 12) gg ggplot object add (default NULL) stats logical whether add statistical tests (default FALSE) stats_test string statistical test use, select ("para_unpaired", "para_paired", "nonpara_unpaired", "nonpara_paired")

title: FlatPlot Colour Selection — get_fp_colour
text: key character name, can "rl_green", "rl_red", "rl_blue", "rl_purple", "rl_orange", "rl_magenta", hex colour

title: SuperPlot Colour Palette Selection — get_sp_colours
text: n integer number colours return scheme character name, colour scheme use Choose one four palettes Paul Tol ("tol_bright", "tol_vibrant", "tol_muted", "tol_light"), Color Universal Design ("cud"). vector colours, e.g. c("#FF0000", "green", "#0000FF").

what: Get shapes for data and summary plots — get_sp_shapes
title: Get shapes for data and summary plots — get_sp_shapes
Get shapes for data and summary plots — get_sp_shapes
Get shapes for data and summary plots — get_sp_shapes
text: n number shapes return shape_logical logical whether use different shapes replicates. Default FALSE, results circle used. TRUE means selection shapes used, data summary points replicate . Four shapes possible, n greater 4, shapes repeat (different colors).

title: Get shapes for data and summary plots — get_sp_shapes
Get shapes for data and summary plots — get_sp_shapes

title: Get statistical test results for the plotted data — get_sp_stats
text: Get statistical test results plotted data

title: Get statistical test results for the plotted data — get_sp_stats
code: get_sp_stats(df, rep_summary, cond, repl, ncond, nrepl, stats_test)

title: Get statistical test results for the plotted data — get_sp_stats
text: df data frame containing data rep_summary summary statistic use testing cond column name condition repl column name replicate ncond number unique values cond nrepl number unique values repl stats_test string statistical test use, select ("para_unpaired", "para_paired", "nonpara_unpaired", "nonpara_paired")

title: Get statistical test results for the plotted data — get_sp_stats
Example cell migration data — lord_jcb
text: Data used Lord et al 2020 generate plots Figs S4 S5

title: Example cell migration data — lord_jcb
text: data frame 300 rows 3 columns: Replicate Experimental replicate number (integer) Treatment Conditions Speed Measurement

title: Make a SuperPlot — superplot
code: superplot(   df,   meas,   cond,   repl,   pal = "tol_bright",   xlab = "",   ylab = "Measurement",   datadist = "sina",   size = c(2, 3),   alpha = c(0.5, 0.7),   bars = "",   linking = FALSE,   rep_summary = "rep_mean",   shapes = FALSE,   fsize = 12,   gg = NULL,   stats = FALSE,   stats_test = "para_unpaired" )

title: Make a SuperPlot — superplot
text: df data frame least three columns: meas, cond, repl meas character name column measurement (e.g. intensity) cond character name column condition (e.g. Control, WT) repl character name column replicate (e.g. unique experiment identifiers) pal name colour palette use (default "tol_bright") xlab string x label (default empty) ylab string y label (default "Measurement") datadist string data distribution use, select ("sina" default, "jitter", "violin") size numeric vector size range data summary points (default c(2, 3)) alpha numeric vector alpha range data summary points (default c(0.5, 0.7)) bars string type error bars add, select ("none" default, "mean_sd", "mean_sem", "mean_ci") linking logical whether link summary points conditions (default FALSE) rep_summary string summary statistic use replicates, select ("rep_mean" default, "rep_median") shapes logical whether use different shapes replicates fsize numeric font size text (default 12) gg ggplot object add (default NULL) stats logical whether add statistical tests (default FALSE) stats_test string statistical test use, select ("para_unpaired", "para_paired", "nonpara_unpaired", "nonpara_paired")
